title: 114_hr6076
content: The Act may be cited as the "To Research, Evaluate, Assess, and Treat Astronauts Act" or the "TREAT Astronauts Act". It includes findings and a sense of Congress. The "TREAT Astronauts Act" acknowledges the risks of human space exploration, including health issues like vision impairment, bone demineralization, and radiation exposure. These risks can lead to long-term health consequences such as cancer and tissue degeneration. To advance long-duration spaceflight missions, astronaut Scott Kelly participated in a 1-year twins study in space while his twin brother acted as a control on Earth. This study provided insights into the effects on the musculoskeletal, central nervous, cardiovascular, and immune systems, as well as vision in space. The Administration currently provides medical monitoring and treatment for astronauts due to unknown long-term health consequences. The Administration seeks statutory authority from Congress to provide medical monitoring, diagnosis, and treatment for former US government astronauts for psychological and medical conditions related to spaceflight. Congress supports continued US leadership in space exploration, recognizing the value of astronaut health data in understanding human diseases. The Administration should provide monitoring, diagnosis, and treatment for unique conditions related to spaceflight for US government astronauts. This should not replace private health insurance and data collected should inform treatment and prevent disease in the astronaut corps. The 340-day space mission of Scott Kelly aboard the ISS was pivotal for the United States' goal of deep space exploration and Mars. It provided new insights into how the human body adapts to weightlessness, isolation, radiation, and long-duration space flight, supporting the well-being of astronauts on future missions. SEC. 3. MEDICAL MONITORING AND RESEARCH RELATING TO HUMAN SPACE FLIGHT. Sec. 20148 of title 51, United States Code allows the Administrator to provide medical monitoring, diagnosis, and treatment for former astronauts and payload specialists for conditions related to human space flight, with no cost sharing required. The medical monitoring, diagnosis, and treatment for former astronauts and payload specialists related to human space flight under Sec. 20148 of title 51, United States Code, must be provided without any cost sharing. Local services can be used if travel to the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center is not advisable. Payment for medical services is secondary to any other obligations. The Administrator will reimburse costs for medical monitoring, diagnosis, or treatment not covered by other provisions, on behalf of former astronauts or payload specialists, as authorized under Sec. 20148 of title 51, United States Code. The Administrator may provide conditional payments for medical monitoring, diagnosis, or treatment not covered by other provisions, if payment cannot be promptly made by the United States or a third party under a contractual agreement. The Administrator may provide conditional payments for medical monitoring, diagnosis, or treatment, with reimbursement required by the United States or a third party. Exclusions include not covering psychological or medical conditions not related to human space flight for former astronauts or payload specialists. The Administrator must ensure privacy of medical records and issue regulations for this section. The definition of a United States government astronaut is specified, excluding international partner astronauts. Data acquired during medical monitoring can be used or disclosed by the Administrator. The Administrator must ensure privacy of medical records for former US government astronauts and payload specialists. Participation in medical monitoring constitutes consent for data disclosure. The Administrator of NASA must publish an annual report on medical monitoring and research related to human space flight, including cost details and a 5-year budget estimate. The Administrator of NASA is required to submit an annual report to Congress on medical monitoring and research for human space flight, including cost estimates. Within 90 days of the Act's enactment, an independent organization will conduct a cost estimate for implementing NASA's activities. The Administrator of NASA must submit an annual report to Congress on medical monitoring and research for human space flight, including cost estimates. An independent organization will conduct a cost estimate for NASA's activities within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a privacy study on potential legal issues related to privacy will be carried out by NASA. The Administrator of NASA will submit a report to Congress on medical monitoring and research for human space flight. NASA will conduct a privacy study on potential legal issues related to data sharing. The Inspector General will audit NASA activities to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse. The Inspector General will audit NASA activities to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse under section 20148 of title 51, United States Code. The House of Representatives passed the document on December 7, 2016, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
